title: Dart has a switch case which can be used instead of long if-else statements:

inline_content.Text: Dart has a switch case which can be used instead of long if-else statements:

title: You can only compare integer, string, or compile-time constants. The compared objects must be instances of the same class (and not of any of its subtypes), and the class must not override ==.

inline_content.Text: You can only compare integer, string, or compile-time constants. The compared objects must be instances of the same class (and not of any of its subtypes), and the class must not override ==.

title: One surprising aspect of switch in Dart is that non-empty case clauses must end with break, or less commonly, continue, throw, or return. That is, non-empty case clauses cannot fall through. You must explicitly end a non-empty case clause, usually with a break. You will get a static warning if you omit break, continue, throw, or return, and the code will error at that location at runtime.

inline_content.Text: One surprising aspect of switch in Dart is that non-empty case clauses must end with break, or less commonly, continue, throw, or return. That is, non-empty case clauses cannot fall through. You must explicitly end a non-empty case clause, usually with a break. You will get a static warning if you omit break, continue, throw, or return, and the code will error at that location at runtime.
